nodes.text: reference to the 1938 Act was omitted because it was regarded as clear that the 1938 Act would continue to operate in cases to which it applied irrespective of the terms of Part V

It is not the case that Reference to the 1938 Act was omitted because it was regarded as clear that the 1938 Act would continue to operate in cases in which it applied irrespective of the terms of Part V
They did not regard it as clear that the 1938 Act would continue to operate in cases to which it applied irrespective of the terms of Part V

Since they did not regard it as clear that the 1938 Act would continue to operate in cases to which it applied irrespective of the terms of Part V their reason for omitting reference to the 1938 Act was not that they regarded it as clear that the 1938 Act would continue to operate in cases in which it applied irrespective of the terms of Part V

had the draftsman conceived that a secure tenant's right to buy could be subject to a condition of ministerial consent under section 5 that right would not have been defined in section 118 in the terms quoted in paragraph 7 above and provision would have been made for asserting and admitting or denying and handling claims to exercise the right to buy where ministerial consent was required.
No provision has been made for asserting admitting or denying and handling claims to exercise the right to buy where ministerial consent was required.
It is their practice not to assume that it is clear that an act continues to operate irrespective of later legislation
the 1938 Act is an instance of their practice
it is the practice of parliamentary draftsmen to show an abundance of caution and to favour the avoidance of doubt.
For parliamentary draftsment showing an abundance of caution and favouring the absence of doubt involves not assuming that it is clear that acts continue to operate irrespective of later legislation
